nodes.bodyText: This is a duplicate of the token below, can be removed
Might want to comment with "Synapse functions" so that it can be a place in the future to group all tokens identifying synapse specific functions
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -234,14 +234,28 @@ TOKEN [IGNORE_CASE]: {
   >
 }
 
+/* Synapse functions
+TOKEN [IGNORE_CASE]: {
+  < synapse_function_name:
+   "CURRENT_USER"
+  >
+} */
+
+/* User Function */

nodes.bodyText:
You might want keep the same pattern as others, when you have a single value for this alias and keep it on a single line:
< current_user_function: "CURRENT_USER" >

You probably don't need the currentUserFunctionName as we already know at this stage that this is the current user function, but you might need an identifier in the code for the type of synapse function. E.g. you could have a SynapseFunctionName enumeration insted.
Might want to rename to SynapseFunctionName
Is not a date-time
Might be LONG?

This can be hard-coded to CURRENT_USER(), unless you need it somewhere else. Might it be that this is a HasFunctionReturnType? (e.g. like the MySqlFunction). How is the return type used? Is it used if the function is in the select clause? E.g. "select current_user() from ..." would need some sort of way to identify the type returned by the select.
You might not want to make this parameter optional, and always include the id of the user in the constructor of the SqlQueryBuilder.
This substitution should go in the SqlTranslatorUtils.translateModel method and should not use the replace from the string but rather the utilities in the Model to build the value of the function.
Unused, can be removed
-> CurrentUserFunctionTest
Debug messages can be removed
You can add an end to end test in the IT100TableControllerTest.
Most likely, since this can be used in the select you will have to implement the HasFunctionReturnType interface.
You might want to add the documentation in the table examples, see SQLSpecification2.csv in lib-javadoc

you might want to add an assertEquals(1, queryResults.getRows().size()) to check the number of rows and additionally you could check also the number of values: assertEquals(1, queryResults.getRows().get(0).getValues().size()) assuming that your query is something on the lines of "select userId from..."
Probably better to add at the end a category that is more generic (e.g. Other Synapse Functions)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -15,6 +15,7 @@ Aggregation Functions,Returns the sample standard deviation of expr (the square
 Aggregation Functions,"Returns the population standard variance of expr. It considers rows as the whole population, not as a sample, so it has the number of rows as the denominator. You can also use VARIANCE(), which is equivalent.",select VAR_POP(expr) from syn123
 Aggregation Functions,"Returns the sample variance of expr. That is, the denominator is the number of rows minus one. ",select VAR_POP(expr) from syn123
 Aggregation Functions,"For each group of the column 'foo', concatenate the distinct values from column 'bar' order by 'bar' descending with a separator character of '#'.  The distinct keyword is optional.  The 'order by' clause is optional.  The separator is optional, with a default separator of ','.","select foo, group_concat(distinct bar order by bar desc separator '#') from syn123 group by foo"
+User Function,"Returns the Synapse userId of the current user.","select * from syn123 where userId = CURRENT_USER()"

nodes.bodyText: You could extract this into its own method, for example replaceSynapseFunctions
Please add a comment that the chain of UnsignedLiteral(unisgnedNumericLiteral... etc is needed for the binding of variables.
You can directly compare the two maps in the assertEquals without having to compare the entryset
You might want to add a test for the getSelectColumns with the currentUser call to check the function return type.
Tested the FunctionReturnType in CurrentUserFunctionTest.java
I will also add a FunctionReturnType check to to SQLTranslatorUtilsTest
This seems to be unused
this can be private
You might want to actually use a USER_ID type, we could add it to this FunctionReturnType enum
missing a space after the :
You might want to add a getter for the user id
I think you can use the new SqlQuery userId variable (you can add a getter to the SqlQuery class) without having to pass it down the chain
You can use the originalQuery.getUserId() (once you add the getter), definetly not 1L :)
We can use the originalQuery.getUserId() (Once you add the getter)
you can pass the originalQuery.getUserId().
This wont' be needed after the FacetModel is modified to user the user in the original query
This wont' be needed as we can use the original query user id
See comments above :)
Might want to add another query that uses the function in the select clause.
Add assert on the number of values, and to make it consistent add the userId as the select clause
You can add a note that the CURRENT_USER() can be used in the select clause as well and the return column type is USERID
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -65,3 +65,4 @@ Reserved Columns,"In this example we are listing all rows that have a current ve
 Operations on LIST columns,"To filter on a list column. Use the HAS() clause, which holds a comma separated list of values. The values in the comma separated list are in a OR relationship meaning that a row matches if it contains any of the values.","select * from syn123 where fooList has ('either this value', 'or this value')"
 Operations on LIST columns,To filter for lists that contain must contain multiple values you will need chain together multiple HAS() clauses with ANDs. Order DOES NOT matter,select * from syn123 where fooList has ('first required value') and fooList has ('second required value') and fooList has ('third required value')
 Operations on LIST columns,"To operate on individual values stored inside a LIST column, use the UNNEST() function. NOTE: This will duplicate rows for all other columns.","select unnest(fooList), count(*) from syn123 group by unnest(fooList)"
+Other Synapse Functions, "Returns the Synapse userId of the current user.","select * from syn123 where userId = CURRENT_USER()"

nodes.bodyText: Always pair a public/protected method with relevant tests
It's probably better to reuse the UserInfo user variable setup in the before.
